expanded_description: This section introduces the key variables that describe circular motion: radius, speed, and period. Students will learn how these quantities relate to each other and begin working with simple formulas to calculate and predict circular motion behavior.

core_concept.principle: Circular motion is described by three main variables—radius (r), speed (v), and period (T)—which are related through simple mathematical relationships.
core_concept.explanation: To fully describe circular motion, we need to know the size of the circle (radius), how fast the object is moving (speed), and how long it takes to complete one full trip around (period). These variables are connected: if you know any two, you can find the third.

image.alt: Diagram of a circle showing radius, an object moving with speed v, and labels for period T
image.caption: The three key variables of circular motion: radius (r), speed (v), and period (T)

sections.introduction: Just as linear motion uses distance, time, and speed, circular motion has its own set of variables. Understanding these variables helps us describe and predict how objects move in circles.

key_concept.definition: Circular motion variables are measurable quantities that completely describe an object's motion around a circle.
key_concept.context: In physics, we use these variables to calculate everything from how fast a merry-go-round spins to how quickly satellites orbit Earth.

classifications.value: The distance from the center of the circle to the object
characteristics: Constant for a given circular path
Determines the size of the circle
classifications.behavior: The radius affects how far the object travels in one complete circle and how much force is needed to keep it moving in that circle.

examples.explanation: The radius is the length of the string from your hand to the ball.
The radius is the distance from the center of the roundabout to the car.
The radius is about 150 million kilometers from the Sun to Earth.

classifications.value: How fast the object is moving along the circular path
classifications.behavior: Speed tells us how quickly the object covers distance along the circular path. In uniform circular motion, speed is constant.

examples.explanation: The tip of a fan blade might move at 5 m/s—that's its speed along the circular path.
A car going around a circular track at 80 m/s (about 288 km/h) has a constant speed if it's uniform circular motion.

classifications.value: The time required to complete one full circle
characteristics: Inversely related to how fast the object circles
classifications.behavior: Period tells us how long each trip around the circle takes. A shorter period means faster circular motion.

examples.explanation: If a merry-go-round takes 4 seconds to spin around once, its period is 4 seconds.
The tip of a clock's second hand completes one circle in 60 seconds, so its period is 60 s.
Earth spins once every 24 hours, so its period of rotation is 24 hours (86,400 seconds).

classifications.note: Don't confuse period with frequency! Period is time per circle; frequency is circles per time. For Grade 9-10, we focus on period.

image.alt: Visual comparison showing radius (distance to center), speed (arrow along path), and period (stopwatch timing one lap)
image.caption: Radius tells you where, speed tells you how fast, period tells you how long per lap

sections.introduction: To understand how radius, speed, and period relate, we first need to know how far the object travels in one complete circle—the circumference.

key_concept.definition: Circumference is the distance around a circle, calculated as C = 2πr, where r is the radius and π (pi) is approximately 3.14.
key_concept.context: Circumference connects the size of the circle (radius) to the distance traveled in one period.

principles.statement: The distance around any circle equals 2 times π times the radius: C = 2πr.
principles.application: If you know the radius, you can calculate how far an object travels in one complete circle.
principles.example: A merry-go-round with radius 5 meters has circumference C = 2 × 3.14 × 5 = 31.4 meters. A horse on the edge travels 31.4 m per revolution.
principles.analogy: Circumference is like the length of a circular racetrack—it's the total distance for one lap.

principles.statement: π (pi) is the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, approximately 3.14159...
principles.application: For quick calculations, we use π ≈ 3.14. For more precision, calculators have a π button.
principles.example: If a circle's diameter is 10 m, its circumference is about 31.4 m (10 × 3.14).
principles.analogy: π is a special number that shows up whenever circles are involved—it's the circle constant.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Circumference
worked_examples.problem: A circular racetrack has a radius of 50 meters. What distance does a car travel in one complete lap around the track?
worked_examples.final_answer: The car travels 314 meters in one lap around the track.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Circumference gives the distance for one complete circle.

sections.introduction: Now we can connect all three variables. Since speed = distance/time, and the distance for one circle is circumference, we get a simple but powerful relationship.

key_concept.definition: For an object in uniform circular motion, speed equals circumference divided by period: v = 2πr / T
key_concept.context: This formula lets you calculate any variable if you know the other two. It's the fundamental relationship of circular motion.

principles.statement: Speed = Circumference ÷ Period, or v = 2πr / T
principles.application: This formula works for any object moving in uniform circular motion—from spinning tops to orbiting planets.
principles.example: If a merry-go-round of radius 4 m takes 8 seconds per revolution, the speed at the edge is v = (2 × 3.14 × 4) ÷ 8 = 25.12 ÷ 8 = 3.14 m/s.
principles.analogy: Think of it like a runner on a circular track: the distance per lap (circumference) divided by the time per lap (period) gives their speed.

principles.statement: The formula can be rearranged to solve for any variable: T = 2πr / v or r = vT / 2π
principles.application: Depending on what you know and what you need to find, you can rearrange the equation.
principles.example: If you know speed and radius, find period: T = 2πr ÷ v. If you know speed and period, find radius: r = vT ÷ 2π.

worked_examples.title: Finding Speed from Radius and Period
worked_examples.problem: A satellite orbits Earth at a radius of 7,000 km (7,000,000 m). It takes 90 minutes (5,400 seconds) to complete one orbit. What is its orbital speed?
worked_examples.final_answer: The satellite's orbital speed is approximately 8,140 m/s (about 8.14 km/s).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Speed in circular motion depends on both radius and period.

worked_examples.title: Finding Period from Radius and Speed
worked_examples.problem: A car drives around a circular track of radius 100 m at a constant speed of 20 m/s. How long does it take to complete one lap?
worked_examples.final_answer: The car takes 31.4 seconds to complete one lap around the track.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Period is circumference divided by speed.

worked_examples.title: Finding Radius from Speed and Period
worked_examples.problem: A merry-go-round horse moves at 5 m/s and takes 12 seconds to go around once. How far is the horse from the center?
worked_examples.final_answer: The horse is approximately 9.55 meters from the center of the merry-go-round.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Radius can be found if you know speed and period.

image.alt: Triangle diagram showing relationships between v, r, and T with formulas
image.caption: The three formulas: v = 2πr/T, T = 2πr/v, r = vT/2π

sections.introduction: The formula v = 2πr/T reveals important relationships between the variables. Understanding these relationships helps you predict how changing one variable affects the others.

principles.statement: If period stays the same, increasing radius increases speed proportionally.
principles.application: On a spinning platform, points farther from the center move faster than points closer to the center—even though they have the same period.
principles.example: On a merry-go-round spinning once every 10 seconds, a horse at 5 m radius moves at 3.14 m/s, while a horse at 3 m radius moves at only 1.88 m/s.
principles.analogy: Think of a record player—the outer edge moves much faster than the label in the center, but both complete one rotation in the same time.

principles.statement: If radius stays the same, decreasing period (spinning faster) increases speed.
principles.application: For a fixed circle, spinning faster means higher speed around the path.
principles.example: A car on a 100 m radius track at 20 m/s has period 31.4 s. If it speeds up to 40 m/s, period drops to 15.7 s—it completes laps twice as fast.

principles.statement: If speed stays the same, increasing radius increases period (takes longer per lap).
principles.application: At the same speed, a larger circle takes more time to go around.
principles.example: Walking at 1 m/s around a small circle (r = 10 m) takes 62.8 s per lap. Around a larger circle (r = 20 m) at the same speed takes 125.6 s per lap.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Speeds on a Spinning Object
worked_examples.problem: A playground merry-go-round spins with a period of 6 seconds. Two children sit on it: one at radius 2 m, another at radius 4 m. Compare their speeds.

step_by_step.step: Calculate speed for child at 2 m
Calculate speed for child at 4 m

step_by_step.explanation: 4.19 ÷ 2.09 = 2. The child at 4 m moves exactly twice as fast as the child at 2 m.

worked_examples.final_answer: With the same period, speed is proportional to radius. Doubling the radius doubles the speed.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For constant period, v ∝ r (speed is proportional to radius).

sections.introduction: Using correct units is essential in physics calculations. Here's how to handle units in circular motion problems.

classifications.value: Standard units for circular motion variables
classifications.behavior: Always convert measurements to these standard units before calculating.

examples.explanation: If radius is 5 km, convert: 5 km = 5,000 m
If period is 3 minutes, convert: 3 min = 3 × 60 = 180 s
If period is 2 hours, convert: 2 h = 2 × 3600 = 7,200 s

principles.statement: All units must be consistent in calculations—usually meters and seconds.
principles.application: Convert any non-standard units before plugging into formulas.
principles.example: A problem gives r = 50 cm and T = 2 minutes. Convert: r = 0.5 m, T = 120 s before calculating v.

principles.statement: Check that your answer has the correct units for what you're calculating.
principles.application: Speed should be in m/s, period in s, radius in m.
principles.example: If you calculate v and get an answer in m/s², something went wrong—that's acceleration, not speed.

sections.introduction: Try these problems to build confidence with circular motion variables.

worked_examples.title: Problem 1: Finding Speed
worked_examples.problem: A bicycle wheel has a radius of 0.35 m. If it takes 0.5 seconds to complete one rotation, how fast is a point on the edge of the wheel moving?
worked_examples.final_answer: A point on the edge moves at approximately 4.4 m/s.

worked_examples.title: Problem 2: Finding Period
worked_examples.problem: A race car travels at 60 m/s around a circular track with radius 300 m. How long does it take to complete one lap?
worked_examples.final_answer: The car takes 31.4 seconds to complete one lap.

worked_examples.title: Problem 3: Finding Radius
worked_examples.problem: A satellite orbits Earth with a speed of 7,500 m/s and a period of 5,400 seconds. What is its orbital radius?
worked_examples.final_answer: The orbital radius is approximately 6,450 km.

worked_examples.title: Problem 4: Comparison Question
worked_examples.problem: Two spinning disks have the same period. Disk A has radius 0.5 m, Disk B has radius 1.5 m. How does the speed of the edge of Disk B compare to Disk A?

step_by_step.explanation: With same T, v ∝ r (speed proportional to radius)
Since radius is 3 times larger, speed is also 3 times larger

worked_examples.final_answer: The edge of Disk B moves 3 times faster than the edge of Disk A.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For constant period, speed ratio equals radius ratio.

sections.introduction: Here are common errors students make when working with circular motion variables—and how to avoid them.

principles.statement: Always convert to meters and seconds before calculating.
principles.application: If radius is given in cm or km, convert to m. If period is in minutes or hours, convert to seconds.
principles.example: Wrong: Using r = 50 cm, T = 2 min → v = 2π(50)/2 = 157 cm/min (incorrect units and value). Correct: r = 0.5 m, T = 120 s → v = 2π(0.5)/120 = 0.026 m/s.

principles.statement: Period is time per circle (seconds). Frequency is circles per second (hertz).
principles.application: Don't mix them up! This section uses period only.
principles.example: If something spins 5 times per second, frequency = 5 Hz, but period = 1/5 = 0.2 seconds.

principles.statement: The formula uses radius, not diameter.
principles.application: If a problem gives diameter, divide by 2 to get radius.
principles.example: Diameter = 20 m means radius = 10 m. Using 20 m in the formula would give double the correct circumference.

summary: Circular motion is described by three key variables: radius (r)—the distance from the center; speed (v)—how fast the object moves along the circular path; and period (T)—the time to complete one full circle. These variables are connected by the circumference formula C = 2πr and the speed equation v = 2πr/T. This relationship allows us to calculate any variable if we know the other two. Understanding these relationships reveals important patterns: with constant period, speed increases with radius; with constant radius, speed increases as period decreases; with constant speed, larger radii require longer periods. By mastering these concepts and practicing unit conversions, students can solve a wide range of circular motion problems, preparing them for more advanced topics like centripetal force calculations.
